metadata.title: The First Green Revolution: The Growth of Production and Productivity in European Agriculture, 1870-1914

dependent_variables.displaced: rapid decline of the number of agricultural labourers
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Real wages of agricultural labourers expressed in kilograms of wheat doubled in almost all European countries between 1870 and 1910

historical_context.economic_conditions: period of agricultural depression and rising nominal wages
historical_context.institutional_context: lack of institutional change in British agriculture, role of cooperatives in continental Europe

outcomes.main_findings: The study found that the rise of small family farms and the decline of large-scale farming based on wage work were significant trends. Innovations such as chemical fertilizers and purchased feed stuffs were land-saving and crucial for agricultural productivity growth.
outcomes.conclusions: The study concludes that the first 'green revolution' led to increased agricultural productivity and a shift towards small family farms in Western Europe, with significant regional differences in adoption and productivity.
